title: R46272
content: The International Trade Administration (ITA), the U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC), and the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) are funded through the annual Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies (CJS) appropriations. This report provides an overview of these agencies' programs and a comparison of the FY2020 CJS proposals with the previous year's enacted legislation. For FY2019, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (P.L. 116-6), provided a total of $647.0 million in funding for the three CJS trade-related agencies. The FY2019 appropriations for the three CJS trade-related agencies was a 0.2% decrease (-$1.3 million) from FY2018 appropriations. For FY2020, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 (P.L. 116-93), provided $678.7 million for the three trade-related agencies. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 (P.L. 116-93) provided $678.7 million for the three trade-related agencies, which was $31.7 million more than FY2019 and $58.5 million more than the Administration's request. The House and Senate passed different versions of their CJS proposals under H.R. 3055, which later became the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 (P.L. 116-93). The President submitted the FY2020 budget request to Congress on March 11, 2019, requesting $620.2 million for three CJS trade-related agencies, $26.8 million less than FY2019. The House Committee on Appropriations passed a bill with $694.0 million for the agencies, $47.0 million more than FY2019 and $73.8 million more than the Administration's request. The Senate Committee on Appropriations reported its CJS bill, S. 2584, with $72.0 million for USTR. The Senate passed H.R. 3055 with amendments, providing $678.7 million for the three CJS trade-related agencies, $31.7 million more than FY2019. The funding levels were enacted in the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 (P.L. 116-93), signed by the President on December 20, 2019. The International Trade Administration received $678.7 million in funding, which was $31.7 million more than the previous year and $58.5 million more than the Administration's request. ITA's mission is to improve U.S. prosperity by promoting trade, enforcing trade laws, and providing export promotion services. It underwent a major organizational change in 2013, consolidating into three units: Global Markets, Enforcement and Compliance, and Industry and Analysis. The International Trade Administration (ITA) has four organizational units: Global Markets, Enforcement and Compliance, Industry and Analysis, and Executive and Administrative Directorate. The FY2020 budget proposal for ITA requested $460.1 million in direct appropriations, with an additional $11.0 million from user fees, totaling $471.1 million. This was $23.9 million less than the FY2019 funding level. The House-passed H.R. 3055 included $521.0 million in direct appropriations for ITA, with an additional $11.0 million from user fees, totaling $532.0 million in authorized spending. The FY2020 budget proposal for the International Trade Administration (ITA) requested $460.1 million in direct appropriations, with an additional $11.0 million from user fees, totaling $471.1 million. The Senate-passed version proposed $510.3 million in direct appropriations for ITA with an additional $11.0 million from user fees, totaling $521.3 million in authorized spending. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 adopted the Senate-proposed funding level of $510.3 million for ITA's top-level funding. The Global Markets unit of the International Trade Administration (ITA) promotes U.S. exports and attracts foreign investment through the SelectUSA program. It helps U.S. exporters research foreign markets, advises on market access and regulations, and facilitates connections through trade shows and missions. The unit also engages with foreign governments to advocate for U.S. firms and resolve market barriers. Additionally, the SelectUSA program promotes the United States as a destination for foreign investment. For FY2020, the Administration proposed reducing funding for the Global Markets unit by $42.0 million (-13.1%) compared to FY2019. They planned to close 32 overseas offices, 18 domestic offices, and reduce personnel by 114 positions to cut operational expenses. However, the House and Senate Committees recommended increasing funding for Global Markets, with the House Appropriations Committee proposing $338.6 million, $18.6 million more than FY2019 and $60.7 million more than the Administration's proposal. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $335.3 million for Global Markets, $15.3 million more than FY2019 enacted amount and $57.3 million more than the Administration's request. The report directed ITA to spend "no less than $130 million on employee compensation" for Global Markets and stated that no office closures would be approved at this funding level. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 provided "no less than $333,000,000 for Global Markets." The Enforcement and Compliance unit enforces U.S. trade laws and ensures compliance with international trade agreements. The Enforcement and Compliance unit enforces U.S. trade laws, oversees trade remedy programs, assists with unfair trade matters, and administers import programs. The Administration proposed $93.8 million for FY2020, a $5.3 million increase from FY2019, to address growing caseloads and establish a team for investigating circumvention and duty allegations. The House-passed version of H.R. 3055 for FY2020 included $94.8 million for Enforcement and Compliance, $6.3 million more than FY2019. The Senate recommended $1 million above the FY2019 level for a dedicated anti-circumvention and duty evasion enforcement unit. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 did not specify funding levels for Enforcement and Compliance. ITA is directed to fill vacancies to support trade promotion, facilitation, and enforcement, as well as staff for the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States and the Anti-Circumvention and Evasion Unit. The Industry and Analysis unit advances U.S. industries' competitiveness through trade and investment policies, export promotion, and market access improvement for businesses. The federal government supports small and medium-sized enterprises through programs like the Market Development Cooperator Program. In FY2020, the Administration proposed increasing funding for the Industry and Analysis unit by $10.0 million (19.1%) compared to the previous year. This increase aims to address issues related to foreign investment, develop staff with economic modeling skills, manage trade processes, and provide analysis for trade negotiations. For FY2020, the House-passed bill included $62.6 million for Industry and Analysis, a $10.0 million (19.1%) increase from the previous year. The Senate did not specify a funding level but recommended providing the requested program changes for Industry and Analysis to implement FIRRMA and enhance analytical capabilities. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020, did not provide specific funding levels but directed ITA to make necessary adjustments for Industry and Analysis, Enforcement and Compliance, and Executive Direction and Administration. The USITC is responsible for trade-related investigations and providing advice on U.S. trade policy. It investigates imports for harming domestic industries or violating intellectual property rights, provides analysis to the President and Congress, and maintains the U.S. tariff schedule. The agency also serves as a federal resource for trade data and policy information. ITA is directed to fill vacancies to support trade promotion, facilitation, enforcement, and the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States. The USITC serves as a federal resource for trade data and policy information, with an annual budget request subject to submission to Congress. The President's FY2020 budget requested $91.1 million for USITC, a decrease from the previous year, while the Commission's independent budget submission requested $101.0 million. The Commission's independent budget submission requested $101.0 million for USITC, which was $6.0 million more than FY2019 funding and $9.9 million more than the President's budget request. The House-passed H.R. 3055 included the same amount, while the Senate-passed version proposed $99.4 million. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 enacted the Senate's funding level. USTR is responsible for developing U.S. international trade policies. USTR, located in the Executive Office of the President, is the principal advisor on trade policy and chief negotiator for international trade agreements. It negotiates with foreign governments, participates in global trade organizations, and engages with various groups on trade policy issues. Funding for USTR includes direct appropriations and supplementary funding from the Trade Enforcement Trust Fund. The Administration requested $69.0 million for USTR in FY2020. The Administration requested $69.0 million for USTR in FY2020, with $54.0 million for salaries and expenses and $15.0 million from the TETF for trade enforcement activities. The House proposed $72.0 million for USTR, $4.0 million more than FY2019 funding. The Senate recommended $69.0 million, with a different distribution of funds but equal to the Administration's request. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 (P.L. 116-93) enacted the Senate's funding levels of $69.0 million for USTR, with $54.0 million for salaries and expenses and $15.0 million from the TETF. Congress has provided funding for specific trade-related programs within agency budgets, including ITA's China trade enforcement, SelectUSA Program, Survey of International Air Travelers, and Trade Enforcement Trust Fund. ITA's Office of China Compliance, established in 2004, enforces U.S. AD/CVD laws and counters unfair trade practices in China. The China Countervailing Duty Group, created in 2010, handles duties on imports from nonmarket economies. Funding details for China AD/CVD activities were not provided in ITA's FY2020 budget justification. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 provided $16.4 million for China antidumping and countervailing duty enforcement in FY2020. SelectUSA promotes the U.S. as an investment market and coordinates resources across federal agencies. ITA's FY2020 budget did not specify funding for SelectUSA. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 adopted the Senate's funding level of up to $10.0 million for SelectUSA for FY2020. ITA's Survey of International Air Travelers (SIAT) gathers statistics about air passenger travelers in the United States to support the travel industry and forecast staffing needs. The Administration proposed a $3.0 million increase for SIAT in FY2020, which was recommended by both the House and Senate within the ITA budget. The Trade Enforcement Trust Fund (TETF) was established by Congress in 2016 to provide additional funding for USTR's trade enforcement activities. Funds from the TETF can be used to monitor and enforce trade agreements, support trade capacity-building assistance, and investigate unfair trade practices. The Trade Enforcement Trust Fund (TETF) was established in 2016 to fund USTR's trade enforcement activities. In FY2020, the Administration requested $10.0 million from the TETF, $5.0 million less than FY2019. Both House and Senate versions of H.R. 3055 included $15.0 million for trade enforcement, $5.0 million more than the Administration's request. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2020 provided $15.0 million for trade enforcement activities from the TETF. In FY2020, $15.0 million was allocated for trade enforcement activities from the Trade Enforcement Trust Fund (TETF), which was $5.0 million more than the Administration's request.
